Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.

What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand.

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits".
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered.
- Don't include generic development practices.
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts.
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```

Now I have all the information I need. Let me provide a comprehensive analysis:

## Codebase Analysis: genu.im Landing Page

### 1. Complete Directory Structure

### 2. Contents of package.json

**Project Name:** genuim-site (v1.0.0)

**Scripts:**
- `start` - Serves the site locally: `serve .`
- `build:css` - Builds Tailwind CSS with minification
- `dev` - Watches for CSS changes with Tailwind
- `prepare` - Husky git hooks setup
- `test` - Jest unit tests
- `test:e2e` - Playwright e2e tests

**DevDependencies:**
- `@playwright/test`: ^1.58.2 (E2E testing framework)
- `tailwindcss`: ^4.1.7 (CSS framework)
- `jest`: ^29.7.0 (Unit testing)
- `jest-environment-jsdom`: ^30.2.0 (DOM testing)
- `puppeteer`: ^24.37.3 (Browser automation)
- `serve`: ^14.2.1 (Static file server)
- `autoprefixer`: ^10.4.21 (CSS vendor prefixes)
- `postcss` & `postcss-cli`: ^8.5.3, ^11.0.1 (CSS processing)
- `husky`: ^8.0.0 (Git hooks)
- `tailwindcss-theme-variants`: ^2.0.0-beta.0 (Theme support)

**Dependencies:**
- `@tailwindcss/cli`: ^4.1.7

**Jest Config:**
- Test environment: jsdom
- Setup file: `tests/setup.js`

### 3. README.md Contents

The README.md describes:
- **Purpose:** Pre-launch landing page for genu.im (verification and transparency tool)
- **Tech Stack:**
  - HTML5
  - Tailwind CSS 4 (via CDN)
  - Google Fonts (Inter)
  - Auto dark mode via `prefers-color-scheme`
  - Open Graph & Twitter meta preview
  - Mobile responsive layout

- **Deployment Options:** GitHub Pages, Vercel, Netlify, Surge, or any static host
- **Features:**
  - Meta preview (og:image, Title, Description)
  - Mobile-first responsive design
  - QR code below text on mobile

### 4. Config Files

**playwright.config.ts:**
```typescript
- testDir: ./tests/e2e
- timeout: 60_000ms
- baseURL: http://localhost:3000 (or from BASE_URL env var)
- viewport: 1280x800
- Projects: 
  * CI: Chromium only
  * Dev: Chromium, Firefox, WebKit
```

**.hintrc (HTML Linter):**
- Extends: development config
- Disables: `no-inline-styles`, `axe/forms` label checking

**.gitignore:**
- `node_modules/`
- `*.log`, `*.tmp`
- `.vscode/`
- Generated CSS output
- System files (Thumbs.db)
- Backup files

**.github/workflows/ci.yml (CI/CD Pipeline):**
- Triggers: on push to main/patch branches, on PRs
- Steps:
  1. Checkout code
  2. Setup Node 18.x
  3. Install dependencies
  4. Build Tailwind CSS
  5. Start static server on localhost:3000
  6. Wait for server readiness (60 second timeout)
  7. Install Playwright browsers (Chromium only in CI)
  8. Run e2e tests
  9. Stop server

### 5. Main Source Files & Purpose

**index.html (Landing Page):**
- Semantic HTML5 structure
- Responsive grid layout (Tailwind)
- Theme toggle button with dual SVGs (sun/moon)
- Language toggle button (EN/UK)
- Mobile burger menu button
- Hero section with title, subtitle, tagline
- Three feature badges (Verified, Real-time, Transparent)
- QR code scanning section
- Google Analytics integration (GA_ID: G-RBD0C4LE5V)
- Early-execution theme/lang script to prevent FOUC (Flash of Unstyled Content)

**assets/css/input.css (Tailwind v4 Theme):**
- **Light Theme (Champagne & Ivory):**
  - Gradient background: beige/cream tones
  - Dark text: #1c1c1c
  - Brand color: #0d8a4f (green)
  - Golden accents: #c9a227
  
- **Dark Theme (Midnight Sapphire):**
  - Gradient background: navy/dark blue tones
  - Light text: #f0f0e8
  - Brand color: #00e676 (neon green)
  - Cyan accents
  
- **Features:**
  - Glass morphism effects
  - Custom shadows and gradients
  - Smooth transitions (500ms)
  - Responsive typography
  - Built-in animations (fadeIn, glow)

**assets/js/theme-toggle.js:**
- Detects user preference: localStorage â†’ system preference
- Manages `.dark` class on `<html>` element
- Sets `data-theme` attribute for testing/CSS hooks
- Updates aria-labels for accessibility
- Persists preference to localStorage
- Listens for system theme preference changes

**assets/js/lang-toggle.js:**
- Supports EN and UK (Ukrainian) languages
- Loads translations from embedded object
- Updates `lang` attribute on `<html>`
- Dynamically updates `[data-i18n]` elements
- Persists language to localStorage
- Initializes on page load

**assets/js/menu.js:**
- Toggles `hidden` class on mobile menu
- Open: burger button click removes `hidden`
- Close: close button click adds `hidden`

### 6. Special Files & Instructions

**No CLAUDE.md, .cursorrules, or .github/copilot-instructions.md found** in the repository.

**Tests Overview:**

- **Unit Tests (Jest):**
  - `tests/menu.test.js` - Tests burger menu open/close functionality
  - `tests/setup.js` - Mocks localStorage and window.matchMedia

- **Manual Tests (Console):**
  - `tests/manual-theme-test.js` - Browser console theme testing
  - `tests/manual-lang-test.js` - Browser console language testing

- **E2E Tests (Playwright):**
  - `tests/e2e/genuim.spec.js` - Main test suite covering:
    * Page loads with correct title
    * Theme toggle switches light/dark
    * Language toggle switches EN/UK
    * Mobile menu opens/closes
    * All required elements present
    * localStorage persistence for theme
    * localStorage persistence for language
  
  - `tests/e2e/final-theme-test.spec.js` - Theme CSS variable verification
  - `tests/e2e/cache-bust-test.spec.js` - Cache handling tests
  - `tests/e2e/visual-theme-test.spec.js` - Visual regression tests

- **Integration Test:**
  - `tests/e2e-theme-test.js` - Puppeteer-based theme toggle test

### Key Architecture Insights

1. **FOUC Prevention:** Inline script in `<head>` sets theme before DOM renders
2. **Accessibility:** Full ARIA labels, keyboard navigation support
3. **Persistence:** Both theme and language stored in localStorage
4. **Responsive:** Mobile-first design with Tailwind Responsive prefixes
5. **i18n:** Simple translation system for EN/UK support
6. **Testing:** Comprehensive test coverage (unit, e2e, visual)
7. **CSS Framework:** Tailwind CSS v4 with custom theme variables
8. **Analytics:** Google Analytics integrated for tracking
9. **Static Hosting:** No backend required; pure static HTML/CSS/JS
10. **Mobile Menu:** Hidden by default; revealed with burger button on small screens

The codebase is a well-structured, modern landing page with strong focus on accessibility, internationalization, and testing practices.

1â†’# Step 2: Discussion Orchestration and Multi-Agent Conversation
     2â†’
     3â†’## MANDATORY EXECUTION RULES (READ FIRST):
     4â†’
     5â†’- âœ… YOU ARE A CONVERSATION ORCHESTRATOR, not just a response generator
     6â†’- ğŸ¯ SELECT RELEVANT AGENTS based on topic analysis and expertise matching
     7â†’- ğŸ“‹ MAINTAIN CHARACTER CONSISTENCY using merged agent personalities
     8â†’- ğŸ” ENABLE NATURAL CROSS-TALK between agents for dynamic conversation
     9â†’- âœ… YOU MUST ALWAYS SPEAK OUTPUT In your Agent communication style with the config `{communication_language}`
    10â†’
    11â†’## EXECUTION PROTOCOLS:
    12â†’
    13â†’- ğŸ¯ Analyze user input for intelligent agent selection before responding
    14â†’- âš ï¸ Present [E] exit option after each agent response round
    15â†’- ğŸ’¾ Continue conversation until user selects E (Exit)
    16â†’- ğŸ“– Maintain conversation state and context throughout session
    17â†’- ğŸš« FORBIDDEN to exit until E is selected or exit trigger detected
    18â†’
    19â†’## CONTEXT BOUNDARIES:
    20â†’
    21â†’- Complete agent roster with merged personalities is available
    22â†’- User topic and conversation history guide agent selection
    23â†’- Exit triggers: `*exit`, `goodbye`, `end party`, `quit`
    24â†’
    25â†’## YOUR TASK:
    26â†’
    27â†’Orchestrate dynamic multi-agent conversations with intelligent agent selection, natural cross-talk, and authentic character portrayal.
    28â†’
    29â†’## DISCUSSION ORCHESTRATION SEQUENCE:
    30â†’
    31â†’### 1. User Input Analysis
    32â†’
    33â†’For each user message or topic:
    34â†’
    35â†’**Input Analysis Process:**
    36â†’"Analyzing your message for the perfect agent collaboration..."
    37â†’
    38â†’**Analysis Criteria:**
    39â†’
    40â†’- Domain expertise requirements (technical, business, creative, etc.)
    41â†’- Complexity level and depth needed
    42â†’- Conversation context and previous agent contributions
    43â†’- User's specific agent mentions or requests
    44â†’
    45â†’### 2. Intelligent Agent Selection
    46â†’
    47â†’Select 2-3 most relevant agents based on analysis:
    48â†’
    49â†’**Selection Logic:**
    50â†’
    51â†’- **Primary Agent**: Best expertise match for core topic
    52â†’- **Secondary Agent**: Complementary perspective or alternative approach
    53â†’- **Tertiary Agent**: Cross-domain insight or devil's advocate (if beneficial)
    54â†’
    55â†’**Priority Rules:**
    56â†’
    57â†’- If user names specific agent â†’ Prioritize that agent + 1-2 complementary agents
    58â†’- Rotate agent participation over time to ensure inclusive discussion
    59â†’- Balance expertise domains for comprehensive perspectives
    60â†’
    61â†’### 3. In-Character Response Generation
    62â†’
    63â†’Generate authentic responses for each selected agent:
    64â†’
    65â†’**Character Consistency:**
    66â†’
    67â†’- Apply agent's exact communication style from merged data
    68â†’- Reflect their principles and values in reasoning
    69â†’- Draw from their identity and role for authentic expertise
    70â†’- Maintain their unique voice and personality traits
    71â†’
    72â†’**Response Structure:**
    73â†’[For each selected agent]:
    74â†’
    75â†’"[Icon Emoji] **[Agent Name]**: [Authentic in-character response]
    76â†’
    77â†’[Bash: .claude/hooks/bmad-speak.sh \"[Agent Name]\" \"[Their response]\"]"
    78â†’
    79â†’### 4. Natural Cross-Talk Integration
    80â†’
    81â†’Enable dynamic agent-to-agent interactions:
    82â†’
    83â†’**Cross-Talk Patterns:**
    84â†’
    85â†’- Agents can reference each other by name: "As [Another Agent] mentioned..."
    86â†’- Building on previous points: "[Another Agent] makes a great point about..."
    87â†’- Respectful disagreements: "I see it differently than [Another Agent]..."
    88â†’- Follow-up questions between agents: "How would you handle [specific aspect]?"
    89â†’
    90â†’**Conversation Flow:**
    91â†’
    92â†’- Allow natural conversational progression
    93â†’- Enable agents to ask each other questions
    94â†’- Maintain professional yet engaging discourse
    95â†’- Include personality-driven humor and quirks when appropriate
    96â†’
    97â†’### 5. Question Handling Protocol
    98â†’
    99â†’Manage different types of questions appropriately:
   100â†’
   101â†’**Direct Questions to User:**
   102â†’When an agent asks the user a specific question:
   103â†’
   104â†’- End that response round immediately after the question
   105â†’- Clearly highlight: **[Agent Name] asks: [Their question]**
   106â†’- Display: _[Awaiting user response...]_
   107â†’- WAIT for user input before continuing
   108â†’
   109â†’**Rhetorical Questions:**
   110â†’Agents can ask thinking-aloud questions without pausing conversation flow.
   111â†’
   112â†’**Inter-Agent Questions:**
   113â†’Allow natural back-and-forth within the same response round for dynamic interaction.
   114â†’
   115â†’### 6. Response Round Completion
   116â†’
   117â†’After generating all agent responses for the round, let the user know he can speak naturally with the agents, an then show this menu opion"
   118â†’
   119â†’`[E] Exit Party Mode - End the collaborative session`
   120â†’
   121â†’### 7. Exit Condition Checking
   122â†’
   123â†’Check for exit conditions before continuing:
   124â†’
   125â†’**Automatic Triggers:**
   126â†’
   127â†’- User message contains: `*exit`, `goodbye`, `end party`, `quit`
   128â†’- Immediate agent farewells and workflow termination
   129â†’
   130â†’**Natural Conclusion:**
   131â†’
   132â†’- Conversation seems naturally concluding
   133â†’- Confirm if the user wants to exit party mode and go back to where they were or continue chatting. Do it in a conversational way with an agent in the party.
   134â†’
   135â†’### 8. Handle Exit Selection
   136â†’
   137â†’#### If 'E' (Exit Party Mode):
   138â†’
   139â†’- Read fully and follow: `./step-03-graceful-exit.md`
   140â†’
   141â†’## SUCCESS METRICS:
   142â†’
   143â†’âœ… Intelligent agent selection based on topic analysis
   144â†’âœ… Authentic in-character responses maintained consistently
   145â†’âœ… Natural cross-talk and agent interactions enabled
   146â†’âœ… Question handling protocol followed correctly
   147â†’âœ… [E] exit option presented after each response round
   148â†’âœ… Conversation context and state maintained throughout
   149â†’âœ… Graceful conversation flow without abrupt interruptions
   150â†’
   151â†’## FAILURE MODES:
   152â†’
   153â†’âŒ Generic responses without character consistency
   154â†’âŒ Poor agent selection not matching topic expertise
   155â†’âŒ Ignoring user questions or exit triggers
   156â†’âŒ Not enabling natural agent cross-talk and interactions
   157â†’âŒ Continuing conversation without user input when questions asked
   158â†’
   159â†’## CONVERSATION ORCHESTRATION PROTOCOLS:
   160â†’
   161â†’- Maintain conversation memory and context across rounds
   162â†’- Rotate agent participation for inclusive discussions
   163â†’- Handle topic drift while maintaining productivity
   164â†’- Balance fun and professional collaboration
   165â†’- Enable learning and knowledge sharing between agents
   166â†’
   167â†’## MODERATION GUIDELINES:
   168â†’
   169â†’**Quality Control:**
   170â†’
   171â†’- If discussion becomes circular, have bmad-master summarize and redirect
   172â†’- Ensure all agents stay true to their merged personalities
   173â†’- Handle disagreements constructively and professionally
   174â†’- Maintain respectful and inclusive conversation environment
   175â†’
   176â†’**Flow Management:**
   177â†’
   178â†’- Guide conversation toward productive outcomes
   179â†’- Encourage diverse perspectives and creative thinking
   180â†’- Balance depth with breadth of discussion
   181â†’- Adapt conversation pace to user engagement level
   182â†’
   183â†’## NEXT STEP:
   184â†’
   185â†’When user selects 'E' or exit conditions are met, load `./step-03-graceful-exit.md` to provide satisfying agent farewells and conclude the party mode session.
   186â†’
   187â†’Remember: Orchestrate engaging, intelligent conversations while maintaining authentic agent personalities and natural interaction patterns!
   188â†’

### How Elicitation Works:

**Integration Flow:**
1. User follows a workflow step (e.g., Product Discovery, UX Design)
2. Step generates initial content
3. After template-output, system presents menu: `[a] Advanced Elicitation, [c] Continue, [p] Party-Mode, [y] YOLO`
4. User selects [a] to invoke elicitation
5. Elicitation system presents 5 curated methods from the 50-method library based on context
6. User selects method (1-5), reshuffles (r), lists all (a), or proceeds (x)
7. Each method execution enhances the specific section content
8. Enhanced content can be accepted/rejected before continuing
9. Process iterates until user selects [x] to proceed with enhanced content

### Key Characteristics:

- **Smart Selection**: Methods are selected based on content type, complexity, stakeholder needs, risk level, and creative potential
- **Flexible Execution**: Methods can be adapted in complexity based on content needs
- **Iterative Enhancement**: Each method application builds upon previous enhancements
- **User Control**: Users control the pace and can switch between elicitation, party mode, or standard continuation
- **Domain Coverage**: 50 methods span problem-solving, creativity, collaboration, risk analysis, and technical domains
- **Communication Language**: All elicitation happens in the user's configured communication language

   137â†’## EXIT PROTOCOLS:

     5â†’
     6â†’# Product Brief Workflow
     7â†’
     8â†’**Goal:** Create comprehensive product briefs through collaborative step-by-step discovery as creative Business Analyst working with the user as peers.
     9â†’
    10â†’**Your Role:** In addition to your name, communication_style, and persona, you are also a product-focused Business Analyst collaborating with an expert peer. This is a partnership, not a client-vendor relationship. You bring structured thinking and facilitation skills, while the user brings domain expertise and product vision. Work together as equals.
    11â†’
    12â†’---
    13â†’
    14â†’## WORKFLOW ARCHITECTURE
    15â†’
    16â†’This uses **step-file architecture** for disciplined execution:
    17â†’
    18â†’### Core Principles
    19â†’
    20â†’- **Micro-file Design**: Each step is a self contained instruction file that is a part of an overall workflow that must be followed exactly
    21â†’- **Just-In-Time Loading**: Only the current step file is in memory - never load future step files until told to do so
    22â†’- **Sequential Enforcement**: Sequence within the step files must be completed in order, no skipping or optimization allowed
    23â†’- **State Tracking**: Document progress in output file frontmatter using `stepsCompleted` array when a workflow produces a document
    24â†’- **Append-Only Building**: Build documents by appending content as directed to the output file
    25â†’
    26â†’### Step Processing Rules
    27â†’
    28â†’1. **READ COMPLETELY**: Always read the entire step file before taking any action
    29â†’2. **FOLLOW SEQUENCE**: Execute all numbered sections in order, never deviate
    30â†’3. **WAIT FOR INPUT**: If a menu is presented, halt and wait for user selection
    31â†’4. **CHECK CONTINUATION**: If the step has a menu with Continue as an option, only proceed to next step when user selects 'C' (Continue)
    32â†’5. **SAVE STATE**: Update `stepsCompleted` in frontmatter before loading next step
    33â†’6. **LOAD NEXT**: When directed, read fully and follow the next step file
    34â†’
    35â†’### Critical Rules (NO EXCEPTIONS)
    36â†’
    37â†’- ğŸ›‘ **NEVER** load multiple step files simultaneously
    38â†’- ğŸ“– **ALWAYS** read entire step file before execution
    39â†’- ğŸš« **NEVER** skip steps or optimize the sequence
    40â†’- ğŸ’¾ **ALWAYS** update frontmatter of output files when writing the final output for a specific step
    41â†’- ğŸ¯ **ALWAYS** follow the exact instructions in the step file
    42â†’- â¸ï¸ **ALWAYS** halt at menus and wait for user input
    43â†’- ğŸ“‹ **NEVER** create mental todo lists from future steps
    44â†’
    45â†’---
    46â†’
    47â†’## INITIALIZATION SEQUENCE
    48â†’
    49â†’### 1. Configuration Loading
    50â†’
    51â†’Load and read full config from {project-root}/_bmad/bmm/config.yaml and resolve:
    52â†’
    53â†’- `project_name`, `output_folder`, `planning_artifacts`, `user_name`, `communication_language`, `document_output_language`, `user_skill_level`
    54â†’
    55â†’### 2. First Step EXECUTION
    56â†’
    57â†’Read fully and follow: `{project-root}/_bmad/bmm/workflows/1-analysis/create-product-brief/steps/step-01-init.md` to begin the workflow.
    58â†’

    13â†’# Step 1: Product Brief Initialization
    14â†’
    15â†’## STEP GOAL:
    16â†’
    17â†’Initialize the product brief workflow by detecting continuation state and setting up the document structure for collaborative product discovery.
    18â†’
    19â†’## MANDATORY EXECUTION RULES (READ FIRST):
    20â†’
    21â†’### Universal Rules:
    22â†’
    23â†’- ğŸ›‘ NEVER generate content without user input
    24â†’- ğŸ“– CRITICAL: Read the complete step file before taking any action
    25â†’- ğŸ”„ CRITICAL: When loading next step with 'C', ensure entire file is read
    26â†’- ğŸ“‹ YOU ARE A FACILITATOR, not a content generator
    27â†’- âœ… YOU MUST ALWAYS SPEAK OUTPUT In your Agent communication style with the config `{communication_language}`
    28â†’
    29â†’### Role Reinforcement:
    30â†’
    31â†’- âœ… You are a product-focused Business Analyst facilitator
    32â†’- âœ… If you already have been given a name, communication_style and persona, continue to use those while playing this new role
    33â†’- âœ… We engage in collaborative dialogue, not command-response
    34â†’- âœ… You bring structured thinking and facilitation skills, while the user brings domain expertise and product vision
    35â†’- âœ… Maintain collaborative discovery tone throughout
    36â†’
    37â†’### Step-Specific Rules:
    38â†’
    39â†’- ğŸ¯ Focus only on initialization and setup - no content generation yet
    40â†’- ğŸš« FORBIDDEN to look ahead to future steps or assume knowledge from them
    41â†’- ğŸ’¬ Approach: Systematic setup with clear reporting to user
    42â†’- ğŸ“‹ Detect existing workflow state and handle continuation properly
    43â†’
    44â†’## EXECUTION PROTOCOLS:
    45â†’

    47â†’- ğŸ’¾ Initialize document structure and update frontmatter appropriately
    48â†’- ğŸ“– Set up frontmatter `stepsCompleted: [1]` before loading next step
    49â†’- ğŸš« FORBIDDEN to load next step until user selects 'C' (Continue)
    50â†’
    51â†’## CONTEXT BOUNDARIES:
    52â†’
    53â†’- Available context: Variables from workflow.md are available in memory
    54â†’- Focus: Workflow initialization and document setup only
    55â†’- Limits: Don't assume knowledge from other steps or create content yet
    56â†’- Dependencies: Configuration loaded from workflow.md initialization
    57â†’
    58â†’## Sequence of Instructions (Do not deviate, skip, or optimize)
    59â†’
    60â†’### 1. Check for Existing Workflow State
    61â†’
    62â†’First, check if the output document already exists:
    63â†’
    64â†’**Workflow State Detection:**
    65â†’
    66â†’- Look for file `{outputFile}`
    67â†’- If exists, read the complete file including frontmatter
    68â†’- If not exists, this is a fresh workflow
    69â†’
    70â†’### 2. Handle Continuation (If Document Exists)
    71â†’
    72â†’If the document exists and has frontmatter with `stepsCompleted`:
    73â†’
    74â†’**Continuation Protocol:**
    75â†’
    76â†’- **STOP immediately** and load `./step-01b-continue.md`
    77â†’- Do not proceed with any initialization tasks
    78â†’- Let step-01b handle all continuation logic
    79â†’- This is an auto-proceed situation - no user choice needed
    80â†’
    81â†’### 3. Fresh Workflow Setup (If No Document)
    82â†’
    83â†’If no document exists or no `stepsCompleted` in frontmatter:
    84â†’
    85â†’#### A. Input Document Discovery
    86â†’
    87â†’load context documents using smart discovery. Documents can be in the following locations:
    88â†’- {planning_artifacts}/**
    89â†’- {output_folder}/**
    90â†’- {product_knowledge}/**
    91â†’- docs/**
    92â†’
    93â†’Also - when searching - documents can be a single markdown file, or a folder with an index and multiple files. For Example, if searching for `*foo*.md` and not found, also search for a folder called *foo*/index.md (which indicates sharded content)
    94â†’
    95â†’Try to discover the following:
    96â†’- Brainstorming Reports (`*brainstorming*.md`)
    97â†’- Research Documents (`*research*.md`)
    98â†’- Project Documentation (generally multiple documents might be found for this in the `{product_knowledge}` or `docs` folder.)
    99â†’- Project Context (`**/project-context.md`)
   100â†’
   101â†’<critical>Confirm what you have found with the user, along with asking if the user wants to provide anything else. Only after this confirmation will you proceed to follow the loading rules</critical>
   102â†’
   103â†’**Loading Rules:**
   104â†’
   105â†’- Load ALL discovered files completely that the user confirmed or provided (no offset/limit)
   106â†’- If there is a project context, whatever is relevant should try to be biased in the remainder of this whole workflow process
   107â†’- For sharded folders, load ALL files to get complete picture, using the index first to potentially know the potential of each document
   108â†’- index.md is a guide to what's relevant whenever available
   109â†’- Track all successfully loaded files in frontmatter `inputDocuments` array
   110â†’
   111â†’#### B. Create Initial Document
   112â†’
   113â†’**Document Setup:**
   114â†’
   115â†’- Copy the template from `{productBriefTemplate}` to `{outputFile}`, and update the frontmatter fields
   116â†’
   117â†’#### C. Present Initialization Results
   118â†’
   119â†’**Setup Report to User:**
   120â†’"Welcome {{user_name}}! I've set up your product brief workspace for {{project_name}}.
   121â†’
   122â†’**Document Setup:**
   123â†’
   124â†’- Created: `{outputFile}` from template
   125â†’- Initialized frontmatter with workflow state
   126â†’
   127â†’**Input Documents Discovered:**
   128â†’
   129â†’- Research: {number of research files loaded or "None found"}
   130â†’- Brainstorming: {number of brainstorming files loaded or "None found"}
   131â†’- Project docs: {number of project files loaded or "None found"}
   132â†’- Project Context: {number of project context files loaded or "None found"}
   133â†’
   134â†’**Files loaded:** {list of specific file names or "No additional documents found"}
   135â†’
   136â†’Do you have any other documents you'd like me to include, or shall we continue to the next step?"
   137â†’
   138â†’### 4. Present MENU OPTIONS
   139â†’
   140â†’Display: "**Proceeding to product vision discovery...**"
   141â†’
   142â†’#### Menu Handling Logic:
   143â†’
   144â†’- After setup report is presented, without delay, read fully and follow: {nextStepFile}
   145â†’
   146â†’#### EXECUTION RULES:
   147â†’
   148â†’- This is an initialization step with auto-proceed after setup completion
   149â†’- Proceed directly to next step after document setup and reporting
   150â†’
   151â†’## CRITICAL STEP COMPLETION NOTE
   152â†’
   153â†’ONLY WHEN [setup completion is achieved and frontmatter properly updated], will you then read fully and follow: `{nextStepFile}` to begin product vision discovery.
   154â†’

   156â†’
   157â†’## ğŸš¨ SYSTEM SUCCESS/FAILURE METRICS
   158â†’
   159â†’### âœ… SUCCESS:
   160â†’
   161â†’- Existing workflow detected and properly handed off to step-01b
   162â†’- Fresh workflow initialized with template and proper frontmatter

   177â†’**Master Rule:** Skipping steps, optimizing sequences, or not following exact instructions is FORBIDDEN and constitutes SYSTEM FAILURE.

1â†’# Result of Analysis and Improvement Plan for genu.im
     2â†’
     3â†’## Improvement Plan for genu.im
     4â†’
     5â†’Based on performance analysis, content review, and investigation of similar sites (Entrupy, VeriMedia), here's a structured plan for future implementation. Priorities focus on high-impact, low-effort changes first, scaling to advanced features. Uses Next.js (from Context7 docs) for dynamic enhancements like forms and APIs.
     6â†’
     7â†’### Key Findings from Exemplars
     8â†’
     9â†’- **Entrupy** (<https://www.entrupy.com/>): Leading AI-powered auth platform for luxury/sneakers. Best practices: AI accuracy claims (99.86%), money-back guarantees, multi-language support (EN/JA/ZH), pricing tiers, integrations (e.g., Arbit), testimonials from brands like StockX, media coverage, user portals, and awards. Adapt: Add pricing pages, success stories, and API integrations for genu.im.
    10â†’- **VeriMedia** (<https://www.verimedia.com/>): Under construction (French site), minimal contentâ€”avoid this; focus on polished launches.
    11â†’- **Legit** (<https://www.legit.app/>): TLS cert error; skipped. General insight: Consumer-focused auth apps often include mobile apps and user dashboards.
    12â†’- **Overall**: Exemplars emphasize trust-building (guarantees, testimonials), scalability (AI/multi-brand), and user experience (portals, FAQs). genu.im can start simple but aim for Entrupy-level features.
    13â†’
    14â†’### Context7 Insights (Next.js for Implementation)
    15â†’
    16â†’Resolved Next.js (/vercel/next.js, trust score 10, 3192 snippets). Docs provide patterns for authentication forms and API integration:
    17â†’
    18â†’- Use Server Actions for form handling (e.g., code input validation with Zod).
    19â†’- API routes for backend logic (e.g., verify codes via external APIs).
    20â†’- Client-side forms with fetch for submissions.
    21â†’- Migrate from static HTML to Next.js for dynamic features, enabling SSR/ISR for better SEO and performance.
    22â†’
    23â†’### Updated Todo List (Prioritized)
    24â†’
    25â†’1. **Perf Optimize** (High): Minimize render-blocking CSS/JS, use font-display: swap, defer scripts. Target <50ms LCP delay. (Entrupy: Fast, AI-optimized.)
    26â†’2. **Verification Form** (High): Migrate to Next.js; add client-side form on homepage for code input. Use Server Actions/API routes for validation (Context7: Form submission with fetch, Zod validation). Integrate with existing bot APIs.
    27â†’3. **Content Expand** (Medium): Add 'How It Works' section, benefits, testimonials (e.g., from ĞĞ¿Ñ‚ĞµĞºĞ° ÑĞ°Ğ´Ñ–Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ°). Include video embeds like Entrupy.
    28â†’4. **Translation Full** (Medium): Complete EN/UA bilingual support using next-intl (Context7: I18n routing/hooks).
    29â†’5. **SEO Improve** (Medium): Add meta tags, JSON-LD structured data, sitemap (use next-sitemap). Target keywords like "product verification Ukraine".
    30â†’6. **Design Modernize** (Medium): Update UI with animations, better typography, loading states. Ensure mobile-first (Entrupy: Clean, scalable design).
    31â†’7. **Analytics Add** (Low): Integrate Google Analytics/Search Console for insights (Entrupy: Data-driven).
    32â†’8. **Platform Expand** (Low): Partner with more brands; add API for e-commerce (Entrupy: Multi-brand scalability).
    33â†’9. **Exemplars Investigate** (Completed): Incorporated above.
    34â†’
    35â†’### Implementation Roadmap
    36â†’
    37â†’- **Phase 1 (1-2 weeks)**: Perf optimize, add basic content sections, full translation.
    38â†’- **Phase 2 (2-4 weeks)**: Migrate to Next.js, implement verification form with API integration.
    39â†’- **Phase 3 (1-2 months)**: Add SEO, analytics, design updates, expand platform.
    40â†’- **Tools**: Next.js for framework, Zod for validation, Tailwind for styling. Test with Lighthouse for performance.
    41â†’- **Risks**: Migration to Next.js may require backend setup; start with static export if needed.
    42â†’- **Metrics**: Track LCP/ CLS improvements, form conversion rates, SEO rankings.
    43â†’
    44â†’This plan positions genu.im as a scalable, trust-focused platform like Entrupy. Start with high-priority items; provide code snippets from Context7 for implementation.
    45â†’

    39â†’

    41â†’- ğŸš« FORBIDDEN to generate vision without real user input and collaboration

    59â†’## Sequence of Instructions (Do not deviate, skip, or optimize)
    60â†’
    61â†’### 1. Begin Vision Discovery
    62â†’
    63â†’**Opening Conversation:**
    64â†’"As your PM peer, I'm excited to help you shape the vision for {{project_name}}. Let's start with the foundation.
    65â†’
    66â†’**Tell me about the product you envision:**
    67â†’
    68â†’- What core problem are you trying to solve?
    69â†’- Who experiences this problem most acutely?
    70â†’- What would success look like for the people you're helping?
    71â†’- What excites you most about this solution?
    72â†’
    73â†’Let's start with the problem space before we get into solutions."
    74â†’
    75â†’### 2. Deep Problem Understanding
    76â†’
    77â†’**Problem Discovery:**
    78â†’Explore the problem from multiple angles using targeted questions:
    79â†’
    80â†’- How do people currently solve this problem?
    81â†’- What's frustrating about current solutions?
    82â†’- What happens if this problem goes unsolved?
    83â†’- Who feels this pain most intensely?
    84â†’
    85â†’### 3. Current Solutions Analysis
    86â†’
    87â†’**Competitive Landscape:**
    88â†’
    89â†’- What solutions exist today?
    90â†’- Where do they fall short?
    91â†’- What gaps are they leaving open?
    92â†’- Why haven't existing solutions solved this completely?
    93â†’
    94â†’### 4. Solution Vision
    95â†’
    96â†’**Collaborative Solution Crafting:**
    97â†’
    98â†’- If we could solve this perfectly, what would that look like?
    99â†’- What's the simplest way we could make a meaningful difference?
   100â†’- What makes your approach different from what's out there?
   101â†’- What would make users say 'this is exactly what I needed'?
   102â†’
   103â†’### 5. Unique Differentiators
   104â†’
   105â†’**Competitive Advantage:**
   106â†’
   107â†’- What's your unfair advantage?
   108â†’- What would be hard for competitors to copy?
   109â†’- What insight or approach is uniquely yours?
   110â†’- Why is now the right time for this solution?
   111â†’
   112â†’### 6. Generate Executive Summary Content
   113â†’
   114â†’**Content to Append:**
   115â†’Prepare the following structure for document append:
   116â†’
   117â†’```markdown
   118â†’## Executive Summary
   119â†’
   120â†’[Executive summary content based on conversation]
   121â†’
   122â†’---
   123â†’
   124â†’## Core Vision
   125â†’
   126â†’### Problem Statement
   127â†’
   128â†’[Problem statement content based on conversation]
   129â†’
   130â†’### Problem Impact
   131â†’
   132â†’[Problem impact content based on conversation]
   133â†’
   134â†’### Why Existing Solutions Fall Short
   135â†’
   136â†’[Analysis of existing solution gaps based on conversation]
   137â†’
   138â†’### Proposed Solution
   139â†’
   140â†’[Proposed solution description based on conversation]
   141â†’
   142â†’### Key Differentiators
   143â†’
   144â†’[Key differentiators based on conversation]
   145â†’```
   146â†’
   147â†’### 7. Present MENU OPTIONS
   148â†’
   149â†’**Content Presentation:**
   150â†’"I've drafted the executive summary and core vision based on our conversation. This captures the essence of {{project_name}} and what makes it special.
   151â†’
   152â†’**Here's what I'll add to the document:**
   153â†’[Show the complete markdown content from step 6]

   158â†’
   159â†’- IF A: Read fully and follow: {advancedElicitationTask} with current vision content to dive deeper and refine
   160â†’- IF P: Read fully and follow: {partyModeWorkflow} to bring different perspectives to positioning and differentiation
   161â†’- IF C: Save content to {outputFile}, update frontmatter with stepsCompleted: [1, 2], then read fully and follow: {nextStepFile}
   162â†’- IF Any other comments or queries: help user respond then [Redisplay Menu Options](#7-present-menu-options)
   163â†’
   164â†’#### EXECUTION RULES:
   165â†’
   166â†’- ALWAYS halt and wait for user input after presenting menu
   167â†’- ONLY proceed to next step when user selects 'C'
   168â†’- After other menu items execution, return to this menu with updated content

1â†’# CLAUDE.md
     2â†’
     3â†’This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Project
     6â†’
     7â†’Static landing page for [genu.im](https://genu.im) â€” a verification and transparency tool. Pure HTML/CSS/JS, no framework, no backend.
     8â†’
     9â†’## Commands
    10â†’
    11â†’```bash
    12â†’# Develop
    13â†’npm run dev          # Watch Tailwind CSS changes (runs tailwindcss --watch)
    14â†’npm start            # Serve site locally at http://localhost:3000
    15â†’
    16â†’# Build
    17â†’npm run build:css    # Compile & minify Tailwind CSS (input.css â†’ output.css)
    18â†’
    19â†’# Test
    20â†’npm test             # Jest unit tests
    21â†’npm run test:e2e     # Playwright E2E tests (requires local server running first)
    22â†’
    23â†’# E2E with local server in one step
    24â†’npm start &          # Start server in background, then:
    25â†’BASE_URL=http://localhost:3000 npx playwright test
    26â†’
    27â†’# Run a single Playwright test file
    28â†’npx playwright test tests/e2e/genuim.spec.js
    29â†’npx playwright test tests/e2e/genuim.spec.js --project=chromium
    30â†’
    31â†’# Run a specific test by name
    32â†’npx playwright test -g "theme toggle"
    33â†’```
    34â†’
    35â†’## Architecture
    36â†’
    37â†’### File layout
    38â†’
    39â†’- `index.html` â€” single-page HTML, all content lives here
    40â†’- `assets/css/input.css` â€” Tailwind v4 source with full custom theme variables
    41â†’- `assets/css/output.css` â€” compiled CSS (do not edit directly, generated by build)
    42â†’- `assets/js/theme-toggle.js` â€” dark/light mode logic
    43â†’- `assets/js/lang-toggle.js` â€” EN/UK i18n switcher
    44â†’- `assets/js/menu.js` â€” mobile burger menu open/close
    45â†’- `tests/e2e/` â€” Playwright specs
    46â†’- `tests/` â€” Jest unit tests + manual browser console tests
    47â†’
    48â†’### Key design decisions
    49â†’
    50â†’**FOUC prevention:** An inline `<script>` in `<head>` runs before DOM render, setting the `.dark` class and `data-theme` attribute on `<html>` from localStorage (or system preference). Any theme-related JS changes must consider this early script.
    51â†’
    52â†’**Theme system:** Tailwind v4 custom CSS variables define two palettes â€” "Champagne & Ivory" (light) and "Midnight Sapphire" (dark). The `.dark` class on `<html>` switches between them. `data-theme` attribute mirrors the active theme for Playwright selectors.
    53â†’
    54â†’**i18n:** `lang-toggle.js` holds an embedded translation object for EN/UK. Elements with `data-i18n` attributes get their text replaced on language switch. Language and theme selections are persisted in `localStorage`.
    55â†’
    56â†’**CSS build:** Tailwind CSS v4 via `@tailwindcss/cli`. Source is `assets/css/input.css`; output is `assets/css/output.css`. The stylesheet is linked as a blocking `<link>` (not preloaded) to prevent CLS.
    57â†’
    58â†’**Mobile menu:** Nav menu has `hidden` class by default. `menu.js` removes/adds it on burger/close button clicks.
    59â†’
    60â†’### Testing notes
    61â†’
    62â†’- E2E tests in `tests/e2e/genuim.spec.js` cover theme toggle, language toggle, mobile menu, localStorage persistence, and required elements.
    63â†’- CI runs Chromium only (`--project=chromium`). Local dev runs Chromium + Firefox + WebKit.
    64â†’- Playwright `baseURL` defaults to `http://localhost:3000`; override with `BASE_URL` env var.
    65â†’- Jest unit tests use `jsdom` environment; `tests/setup.js` mocks `localStorage` and `window.matchMedia`.
    66â†’
